title: 111_hr3061
content:
The Act titled "Pine River Indian Irrigation Project Act of 2009" is established for the purpose of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project. Congress finds that drought, population increases, and environmental needs are worsening water supply issues in the western United States, including on the Southern Ute Indian Reservation in Colorado. A 2006 report by the Government Accountability Office highlighted significant issues with the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project, with estimated deferred maintenance costs exceeding $20-60 million. The report also showed severe deterioration of key project facilities and insufficient operations and maintenance fees. The Government Accountability Office report highlighted issues with the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project, including deteriorated facilities and insufficient maintenance fees. Benefits of rehabilitating the infrastructure include water conservation, increased agricultural production, and economic benefits. The purpose of this Act is to assess and improve the infrastructure of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project, managed by the Bureau of Indian Affairs, to enhance water management and address potential water conflicts for the Southern Ute Indian Tribe. The Act aims to assess and improve the infrastructure of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project, establish priorities for rehabilitation, and implement necessary activities. The Act defines key terms such as "Project," "Secretary," "State," "Tribal Council," and "Tribe." It also includes a provision for studying the irrigation infrastructure of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project. The Act mandates a study of the irrigation infrastructure of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will develop a list of recommended activities for repair, rehabilitation, or reconstruction over a 10-year period. Priority will be given based on a review of priority factors. The Act mandates a study of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project's infrastructure. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will prioritize recommended activities for repair, rehabilitation, or reconstruction based on threat to health and safety and projected benefits upon completion of the Project. The Bureau of Indian Affairs, the general public, and the Tribe are involved in assessing the disrepair of the irrigation infrastructure of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project. The study will determine the impact on agricultural land irrigation, water conservation opportunities, and the economic and cultural effects on the Tribe. The study will assess the impact of repairing the irrigation infrastructure of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project on the Tribe's economic and cultural benefits, water supply, environmental conflicts, and overall efficiency of water operations on tribal land. The Secretary will consult with relevant federal officials during the study. The Secretary for Indian Affairs and relevant Federal and local officials will assess programs that can be used to develop a list of recommended activities and submit a report to congressional committees and the Tribe within 18 months. The report will include recommended activities and findings from the study on repairing the irrigation infrastructure of the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project. The Secretary, in consultation with the Tribe, will conduct a biennial review of the report on recommended activities for the Pine River Indian Irrigation Project. This review will involve updating the list of activities based on specified factors. SEC. 5. IRRIGATION INFRASTRUCTURE GRANTS AND AGREEMENTS. The Secretary may provide grants or cooperative agreements to the Tribe for irrigation infrastructure projects recommended on a list. Assistance cannot be used for on-farm improvements. Consultation with the Tribe and coordination with relevant entities are required. Cost sharing is also a requirement. The Bureau of Indian Affairs program requires cost sharing for activities, with the Federal share not exceeding 75%. The Secretary can waive or limit the non-Federal share upon the Tribe's request. SEC. 6. EFFECT OF ACT.

(a) Water Rights of Tribe.--This Act does not impact the Tribe's water rights under Federal or State law.
(b) State Water Law.--This Act does not preempt or affect State water laws or interstate compacts.

SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

(a) Study.--$4,000,000 is authorized for the study under section 4.
(b) Irrigation Infrastructure Grants and Agreements.--$10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2015 for irrigation infrastructure grants and agreements.
